name: The House Across the Lake: A Novel

title: This book was amazing
content: Just when you think you have to figure it out , the author throws a loop And really plays with your mind!  I loved the characters,, they were so exciting to read and try to figure out their story.  The story line was wonderful!!  There were so many twists and turns that I didn't see coming. This book will keep you on your toes!
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: Riley Sager‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe House Across the Lake‚Äù is a murder mystery combined with a thriller. Because the promotional materials (the ‚Äúblurb‚Äù) and some of the reviews so adequately describe the premise, I'm not going to summarize the plot, especially since I don‚Äôt want to risk giving away any of the twists, turns, or surprises. And there are more than a few!
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2022

title: A devilishly "bonkers" plot!
content: As Mr. Sager states in his ‚ÄúAcknowledgments‚Äù at the end of the novel, this book has a ‚Äúbonkers plot.‚Äù Which means it has plusses and minuses.  On minus side, the beginning of the novel seemed, in places, not believable.  Characters said and did things that had me scratching my head. The main character suffers from alcoholism that seems to have been brought on by parental neglect, if not abuse, not to mention the death of her husband, also the victim of parental abuse.  All that, combined with a glaring similarity to Alfred Hitchcock‚Äôs ‚ÄúRear Window,‚Äù almost had me closing the book to move on to something else.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: But on the plus side, I found the book well-written, scenes well-constructed, the Vermont lake setting well-described and utilized, and the characters well-drawn and interesting. They include a successful ‚Äúworking actress‚Äù (as opposed to a glitzy movie star), her musical-comedy mega-star mother, a retired super-model, her tech-titan husband, and a hunky ex-police officer with something of a checkered past. And so, I kept going.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2024

title: What the fudge happened
content: Only to find that the plot is devilishly ‚Äúbonkers‚Äù and that Mr. Sager seems to delight in leading his readers down false trails as foggy and mysterious as the paths around his fictional Lake Greene.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: Now, that‚Äôs not to say that readers won‚Äôt have to ‚Äúwillingly suspend their disbelief‚Äù sometimes, and in some pretty big ways.  The ‚Äúreveal‚Äù of what‚Äôs actually going on is fairly stunning and certainly creative and original. Indeed, I don‚Äôt believe I‚Äôve ever read or heard of anything quite like it.  Those who are able to ‚Äújust go with it,‚Äù should find themselves enjoying what I ultimately thought was a very entertaining novel.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2024

title: Twists
content: I was really looking forward to reading this book. It seemed promising. And at first it was good. The main character (forgot her name that‚Äôs how unimpressed I was) is an actress who went off the deep end and became an alcoholic after the husband dies. She becomes obsessed at watching her neighbors across the lake through binoculars (hence the name of the book). Then the wife from that house disappears and she‚Äôs trying to figure out what‚Äôs happens and she believes she‚Äôs been killed. The book switches from past to present while you‚Äôre trying to figure out who the main character is with (presumed killer). I definitely did not expect who was with her. But tbh the plot is just really confusing cause she knows who the real killer is and then there paranormal crap and this book had me in the first half but then I was just trying to get it over with. All in all, it was just ok.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2024

title: Good Read
content: This book had enough twist and turns to make any roller coaster look tame, plus enough ‚Äúghost story‚Äù to make me be uncertain if I ever want to swim in a lake again! Casey, a fired actress and recent widow tries to drown her sorrows in bourbon while hanging out in her family‚Äôs summer lake home and pique her boredom by spying on the power couple across the lake with her dead husband‚Äôs binoculars. The story involves a serial killer, poisoning, betrayal, murder, ghosts and suicide; all blended into a who-dun-it that keeps you guessing and ultimately, family, friendship and loyalty- the ‚Äúgood guys‚Äù should always win!

title: Verified Purchase
content: Without fail, I will always look forward to a new Riley Sager book. Over the years, this anticipation has fluxed between honest enjoyment to cringy disappointment. I loved his early books were clearly fun reboots of canon horror films. I loved that they had the same flashy appeal as summer blockbusters. They are quick to read, easy to enjoy, and merit more than a few audible gasps. My love of Riley Sager's work peaked at Lock Every Door and plummeted to a new low with his last book, Survive the Night. So, it was with cautious optimism that I requested an advance copy of The House Across the Lake.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2022

title: great
content: Told in a split narrative that divides the book chronologically, we follow the functionally drunk and recently widowed actress, Casey Fletcher, to her family's lake home in Vermont. There we sink comfortably into a Rear Window-style frame story as Casey spies on her neighbors from the relative seclusion of her porch. While we sit with Casey, a glass of bourbon in hand, we drift along with her stream of conscious ramblings on the past and musing on the present.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2022

title: Verified Purchase
content: This is a comfortable thriller read. By that I mean that I didn't find myself on the edge of my seat, but I was invested in the story and wanted to see where it would go. Per usual, Sager pulls no punches with his twists and layers in an element of the supernatural to spice up the mystery. Because of this, I understand why there is serious divide about this book.  While I love a good haunting, I felt like Sager didn't fully execute that portion of the story. I wanted to be more creeped out, more haunted. Instead, I was strapped with a narrator that was so focused on not being haunted that the paranormal elements fell flat. I like them, but I was not enthusiastic about them. I don't want to spoil anything, but I will say that I expected the narrator to at least ponder the haunting stories of the lake more as they would relate to the central story Sager was trying to tell. Especially since her family was one of the first to build on the lake and have consequently been there the longest. I just didn't buy it.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2024

title: I still love you Riley Sager. I will keep reading your books. But I know you can be better.
content: I still love you Riley Sager. I will keep reading your books. But I know you can be better.

title: Quite the thriller
content: I recently read The House Across the Lake by Riley Sager.  This is the story of Casey, who is a popular actress.  She has lost her husband and her grief has driven her to drink.  Her drinking caused her to lose her job, starring in a Broadway show. Casey tries to escape the gossip mill by taking an extended summer vacation at a beautiful lake in Vermont. At her waterfront home, she spends most of her time on the back porch, drinking bourbon and watching people through her binoculars. Specifically, she is watching the fancy house with loads of glass, owned by supermodel Katherine and her tech savvy husband, Tom.  Casey's spying losses it's attraction when Katherine goes missing and she suspects Tom.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: This book is quick moving and a true thriller.  This has that, hold your breath, something is about to happen any second feeling.  It is very successful at raising your pulse. It's really amazing the story that Sager weaves with a limited cast and setting.  I think you'll be surprised by the numerous twists.  The author is masterful at making you think you have the story figured out only to slap the back of your hand with a twist that says, "guess again."
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2024

title: Well, that was unexpected.
content: I‚Äôll start by saying that if unreliable, drunk narrators aren‚Äôt your thing, then stay away from this novel. Casey heavily drinks and/or is drunk for the majority of this book. She‚Äôs also alone in her lake house most of the time, which takes the unreliable factor to the next level. Also be warned that there are heavy elements related to grief and regret laced throughout the story.

With that, you might find it more gripping if you read it from start to finish. I personally didn‚Äôt really connect with Casey, so I didn‚Äôt find myself engaged in the story until well past 200 pages.

title: Verified Purchase
content: It‚Äôs hard to know how to rate this book. When I thought it was a simple who-done-it, I was planning on rating this three and a half stars. This was the first book I‚Äôve read for pleasure in about ten years. As I made my way through the story, I was convinced that this would be a cute cozy-mystery that I would enjoy in the moment and then quickly forget. It did a great job of keeping me turning the pages. I consider myself a slow reader so I was shocked when I finished this book in three days. I had plenty of theories on how anybody could be guilty and I thought I was fully prepared for any twist.

title: Clever and Terrifying
content: Casey Fletcher is the daughter of an acting legend. She has a career of her own, but at the moment, she‚Äôs too busy being an alcoholic to continue in that profession. Ordered to the family lake house by family after being fired from her Broadway play for showing up drunk and going on that way, she now wanders through said house in the middle of nowhere in Vermont, soaking herself in bourbon following the accidental drowning of her husband over a year before. One afternoon, she spots a body in the lake from her back porch and motors out to investigate. She saves the life of former supermodel Katherine Royce, who lives across the lake with her millionaire husband Tom. They become friendly, until Casey begins to suspect Tom is threatening harm to Katherine and may be slowly poisoning her. Casey watches day and night with high powered binoculars and thinks she sees a murder. But she has no proof.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: It‚Äôs a familiar-sounding scenario, most recently used in ‚ÄúThe Woman In The Window‚Äù. An unreliable narrator, drinking heavily, who cannot be trusted. For about 2/3 of the way, that‚Äôs the way it progresses. But then, the story turns into something more sinister and the thriller you‚Äôve been reading turns into something much different, something darker and more sinister. And you can‚Äôt stop turning the pages.

title: Couldn't put it down!!
content: Casey Fletcher, an actress suffering from recent bad press, is banished to her family‚Äôs house on exclusive and remote Lake Green after the death of her husband and her subsequent deterioration into alcoholism.  She‚Äôs a train wreck to say the least, but the perfect narrator for this unusual tale that is part crime mystery, part psychological suspense, and part supernatural thriller.

title: Verified Purchase
content: The story has a bit of Rear Window vibe with Casey watching her neighbors across the lake through binoculars‚Äîa tech mogul and a supermodel who live in a lavish glass house. There‚Äôs also a former cop with a murky past who lives next door. The way in which the lives of these four characters intertwine kept me repeatedly second-guessing what I thought I knew about each. Oh, such a clever author! I love the way in which Sager introduces a plot thread only to have it corkscrew it in an entirely different direction later. Fair warning that the ending is ‚Äúout there,‚Äù but for pure story satisfaction and reading enjoyment you can‚Äôt go wrong with The House Across the Lake!

title: No thanks
content: Casey a rather famous actress of both screen and stage, has had a setback, her drinking has caught up to her, and now she is exiled to her families lake front property. Katherine a retired Supermodel and her husband Tom a tech giant also own a home on the lake. As Casey drinks, daily, and a lot she finds an old pair of binoculars, and she starts watching the lake and her neighbors. While watching she notices something or someone on the lake. She takes her boat out to investigate, only to discover and save Katherine. What happens next is what most would think, Tom obviously is trying to kill his wife, but why. The House Across The Lake will leave you with many twists and unexpected turns. A very goid book to bring in the New Year, because this book ends on this very day.

title: Verified Purchase
content: Casey was so annoying that I didn't want to finish the story, despite the fact that I thought it was a good story with interesting supporting characters and a pretty good ending.  Casey was, as I've found in many books these days, an annoying main female character.  Let's see ... she's a spoiled brat, a liar, a drunk, a meddler and a lot of other things.  She made everything worse, not better, and I truly believe that her husband dying and her mother not treating her in the best way really was reason enough for her to behave the way she did.  Even though I didn't want to finish the book, I did so that I could give it a fair review.  So, let's see ... three stars ... for the supporting characters, the plot, the location and ending.  I deducted two stars for Casey's obnoxious personality.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2023

title: Wild Ride
content: I love Riley Sager books, and this one was no exception. It is about an actress named Casey who goes to her mother's lake house alone to come to grips with her husband's death and her alcoholism. She comes to know the neighbors across the lake, spending many evenings on her porch with a bottle of bourbon and a pair of binoculars. The first half of the book is a slow simmer. Then when the second half begins, it's like a wild roller coaster ride with twists and turns. I could not put the book down until the end. I gave this four stars because of the slow start, but it was an awesome read.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 26, 2022

title: Verified Purchase
content: Casey has returned to her family's lake house in Vermont at the will of her mother. Amidst her day drinking, Casey starts a new hobby- watching her neighbors. She meets her new neighbor Katherine and a budding friendship begins...until Katherine seemingly disappears. Casey is determined to find out what happened to Katherine.

title: Different but good
content: About 2/3 of the way through, I was like "I think I know this twist, but I can't know the twist because that's just too obvious for Sager" and I did not know the twist. And honestly, I'd be surprised if ANYONE calls this twist because while there are some clues...it's just...well it's kind of out there...I wasn't sure how much I liked THE twist but it grew on me, and I really like how the book wrapped up. Different, but good!

title: Verified Purchase
content: I loved this book!  Sometimes I just want an easy read, or a scary read or a different read.  This book was all three.  I read it in a couple of days.  It is a page turner.  At first glance it‚Äôs a typical thriller:  missing wife, husband a suspect, and an unreliable witness.  I thought it was going to a copy of The Woman in the Window.  But without giving anything away, it ventures unexpectedly into the supernatural which gives it an interesting twist.  The book surprised me with an unusual ending.  A very enjoyable read.
